"The last time the stock was at these levels, numbers were actually lower so estimates have been revised up, the stock is cheaper, we think it's a strong company, the model is intact," said Binger.
Binger says the company has soothed investor anxiety with better-than-expected earnings and user metrics, a comforting sign that the social network will survive the scandal.
"I see a lot of technical damage that has been done in this stock," Craig Johnson, chief market technician at Piper Jaffray, told CNBC's "Trading Nation" on Friday.
"You've also got the 50-day moving average closing back below the 200-day moving average which is technically considered a bit of a death cross."
"I'm not rushing back into this stock at this point in time from a chart perspective as I think there's going to be just a failed relief rally."
Using past data scandals as a guide, Johnson says Facebook's shares likely have more work to do to prove they have better days ahead of them.
"We own the stock, we have no intention of selling it, we're very comfortable holding it here," Binger said on Friday's "Trading Nation."
That controversy involved a data firm compiling third-party app data on the social network's users to target political advertisements.

Equifax plummeted last year amid a data breach that exposed more than 140 million users' information.
A stock marks a death cross when the 50-day moving average crosses below the 200-day moving average.
Facebook endured heavy sell-offs in the weeks after the Cambridge Analytica scandal broke in March.
As of Friday's close, Facebook shares trade 4 percent below all-time intraday highs set on Feb. 1.
Facebook has ricocheted back to prescandal levels and is now within reach of record highs again.
The charts tell a different story, says Craig Johnson, chief market technician at Piper Jaffray.
At its worst, the stock had tanked more than 19 percent and was on the cusp of a bear market.
Since the scandal broke on March 17, Facebook has risen 1 percent to above $187 a share.
Since hitting a multiyear low on Sept. 14, the stock has rebounded nearly 28 percent.
"As I look at this name, I think you got to be a little bit more careful," he said.
Facebook bull Michael Binger of Gradient Investments sees the stock heading higher.
While it has bounced back and then some, Johnson sees hidden damage on the charts.
The stock lost as much as 14 percent in one single trading day in September.
The technical move usually indicates the beginning of a bearish trend.
"I think it's going to be a show-me story," Johnson said of Facebook.
"Look at the chart of Facebook compared to Equifax," said Johnson.
"Equifax you had a huge data scandal there.
That's what you got to be watching."
